transcript_whisper: So I started using drugs when I was 12 years old. Really I just wanted to fit in with everyone, you know, smoking weed and drinking and doing a lot of LSD actually. McShin had one female house and two male houses at the time back in 2007. And I lived here for five months. I worked. I had my driver's license and a car. And I did odd jobs for all those five months. You know, recovery was really taught to me living in this environment, living in a house with other women that were trying to get their life together. And now the McShin Foundation, we have 15 recovery homes. We have our women and children recovery house, which I've been wanting to do since the day I started working here. title: David Hill's Story - episode 171

transcript_whisper: I grew up in probably your standard households, you know, two parents, both of master's degrees. We moved around a little bit when I was a kid. My parents were both educators and my dad was really chasing a career, so we moved a little bit. And I always had the sense of I didn't fit in. I was sort of awkward and didn't do well with my peer group necessarily. And so I never really feel like I had a place and or a community. When I was in high school, I felt that I was called to be a nurse. So when I graduated high school, I went to nursing school and had a really great nursing career. I moved away from Texas up to Boston and was doing some nursing consulting work, fell down some stairs and had a back injury and a broken tailbone. So I went to the emergency room and I was immediately prescribed opioids and Xanax to help with pain. And to this day, I'm not really sure why they gave me Xanax, but I took it. But what the experts didn't know was that there was a history of addiction in my family. There is a history of mental health issues in my family. And now we know that there is correlation between people who have addiction and family history and mental health issues. So as much as the doctors did prescribe it and continued to prescribe it for years, they can't be solely responsible because we didn't have all the information that we needed at the time this happened. And also, we can't expect every physician prescribing any type of medication, but especially a controlled substance, to be able to have the time to say, tell me about your family. Is there a history of addiction? And is there a history of mental health issues? I mean, I wish that we had a health system in the United States that did that, but that's not what we currently have. And that's not what we had when I became addicted almost 20 years ago. I still have friends in the medical community and I was in the medical community. So I see both sides, especially now because I have now some personal perspective and some professional perspective and now an expert's perspective on prevention. But with the medical knowledge I have now, I realize that there are a lot of solutions that we could offer to the medical community, but they're not yet at a place to really embrace the solutions. And we're always, this is a change. Change is hard, but it's necessary. Change at the level we're talking about, systemic change is incredibly hard to do. It's incredibly expensive and it takes a lot of voices to get us there. And it's not just the medical community. It's not just your physicians and nurses and pharmacists. It's your pharmaceutical companies. It's your lobbyists. It's your congressmen and it's insurance companies. We need systemic change. The best way I can explain what happened before opioids and what happened after, and maybe, I don't know that it was something that happened to me that I could have changed, but I can tell you that by the third or the fourth day of me using opioids to treat physical pain was that I felt like a light switch had gone on. And all of a sudden, I was seeing the world in different colors. I was not as socially awkward. I felt more comfortable with myself. We moved from, I moved from treating physical pain to treating emotional pain. But the best way I can explain that to someone who maybe has never used drugs or never had my experience was it was like a light switch. And every time I took a pill, I liked the light coming on. And I can tell you, I know the room I was in, the address I was in when I felt that phenomenon for the very first time. It is now a core memory. That first light switch was pretty cool. The ones that followed for a little while still felt pretty good. But at some point, I did definitely develop a tolerance to the medication itself, which is physical tolerance, not an emotional tolerance, although that does come into play. But I was also experiencing withdrawal symptoms when I would stop taking opioids and know whenever had, and even though I was a nurse and could have done my own research on opioids. Know whenever had a conversation with me about, you know, you really need to be cautious when you're taking these medications and this is why. And if you stop taking them abruptly, this is what you're going to experience. And this was at the height of the fentanyl or the opioid crisis in Massachusetts, which is really was super fascinating to me because the doctors were prescribing, but it was the pharmacist who had recently, the state had recently mandated a prescription drug monitoring program or a PDMP. So the doctors were writing the prescriptions as fast as they could. And I was going to as many doctors as I could to get those prescriptions, but it was only the pharmacist saying, I see you got this filled four days ago by another doctor. Why are you coming to me now? Which it's fascinating to me to look back and to know that at the time, you know, the East Coast was experiencing some of the worst years of their opioid crisis. The physicians were not part of the solution, only the person dispensing the actual drug. So the pharmacist caught on. So I had more trouble filling the prescriptions. What does someone do when they can't get their opioids from a medical professional? They find other ways. So I found other ways and started buying up the street. So I, you know, I purchased at the pharmacy and was also, you know, buying on the street. But I did that for probably a year. And then my sister-in-law at the time died of a drug overdose. Of course, now we don't know what, you know, they didn't do a lot of testing. It was just labeled a drug overdose. So we're not even sure what, what the drug was. So I don't know if it was poisoning of a fentanyl or of something else. But I realized that I didn't want to have that happen to me and to my family. But I also didn't know how to do anything differently than I'd been doing for several years at that point. A lot of that recognition came from just the amount of pills I was consuming a day. Because not only did I have, you know, withdrawals when I stopped using, but the physical tolerance just got more and more extreme. And I still have that tolerance to this day. You know, haven't taken, you know, a non-prescribed opioid, I'll say, you know, in over 13 years. But the physical tolerance really became a problem. And I mean, at the end of my active addiction, I was taking upwards of 100 pills a day because I would take so many opioids. Yeah, that they would make me itch. So I would take Benadryl. And the Benadryl, you know, had a side effect, so I would take another pill. And I would, all of this made me edgy, so I would take another pill. So yeah. I was living in Texas again, and I didn't have any pills. And I couldn't get them as easily here as I was able to in Massachusetts. It was, I didn't have maybe the connections that I needed, or it wasn't in the right neighborhood. I'm not really sure. But I just, I couldn't buy off the streets anymore. I just didn't know who to go to and who to ask. So I was really a lot more dependent on getting it from physicians. And Texas didn't have a prescription drug monitoring program at the time. So the pharmacists weren't wise. The physicians weren't aware. So for a long time, I went, I doctor shopped. And the pharmacists couldn't tell where I was getting any prescription. So I would just go to different pharmacies each day, or, you know, every week or so. But at some point, the doctors started suspecting that I might have a addiction problem, but they wouldn't have that conversation with me. They would just say, I'm sorry, I can't prescribe. So there was no conversation of, you may need to let us help you. There was no conversation of, you could really, you could harm yourself. You know, what you could do as an alternative or how they could help. I was just cut off. And so I called in a prescription to the pharmacy myself. And I got arrested at the pharmacy. So I was arrested at the pharmacy. My family at the time, I don't think had any clue as to how extreme my problem was. I know now that they were suspecting, my mom especially was suspecting that there was, you know, some misuse going on. But she had, I don't think she had any, you know, comprehension of how bad the problem was until she got a phone call from the police. So I was arrested. And the condition of me getting out of jail was that I would go to treatment. So within four or five days, I was in a 28 day residential treatment center. And I had the privilege to do that because my family was able to pay the cash to get me into treatment. A lot of people don't have that privilege. So for the first 16 days, I was only there because that's what my family wanted me to do. And then day 17, my head was really starting to clear. You know, more, I had gotten a lot of the drugs out of my system and I was really able to evaluate the situation, you know, a little more objectively and see that I had a lot of consequences and it was going to take a lot of work to overcome them. And some I probably would never overcome. And so day 17 through 28, I probably got the most use out of the cash that was paid. Being arrested was the best thing that's happened to me, which you don't hear a lot. I get it. I work with law enforcement and every time someone hears me say that for the first time, we have to have a conversation about it. My first job out of treatment and after a few months of, you know, stabilization was at Starbucks because they didn't do a background check. So that was interesting. Surgery, you know, after, you know, heavily misusing opioids was a difficult process. But it was when I moved from the Dallas area to San Antonio and I got connected with a 12 step group here, which I'm no longer in the 12 step fellowship, but I think that they can be beneficial. But someone in that group said, we like you should work at a, you would be really great like a treatment center or something. So I applied for a job at Sakata and worked as a recovery coach in the recovery and adult services department for a year. But the work that I was doing was some in the community, you know, going out and meeting partners and doing training with professionals to talk about language we use to educate people about why we say substance use disorders and why that's important and what does the data say. So I really liked the community work. And I really liked then policy, it was policy change. I didn't, I wasn't able to articulate that at the time. But Sakata has a coalitions that work mostly in policy. How do you change a business policy to make things safer? How do you change a bars policy to make things safer? How do you make, how do you change city, county, state or federal policy? So I really thought that that was something that I would be good at doing. And so I, there was an opening in the coalition department and I interviewed and moved departments and that's been five years. The recovery? I wouldn't say that. Not now. I would say that the first one to two years were hard because I was essentially rebuilding an identity and rebuilding a future that was a healthy one. So it was hard because there have to be a lot of changes with friend groups, with communities, with thought process and that is all hard to do. So yes, the first one to two years was hard, but it'll be 14 years in January and I really am not at a place where I count days anymore. I haven't counted days in a long, long time. But now with 13, almost 14 years of perspective, it's not hard at all. It's pretty cool. I get to have relationships with my families that are meaningful. I have the privilege of one of my oldest nieces coming to visit today, or my oldest niece coming to visit today. I have the privilege of taking my youngest niece to the museum that she loves. I get to... You know, I get to care for my aging parents. I would not have had that without recovery.
title: Rebuilding a future

transcript_whisper: I'm here because I want to make a difference. I can't say that I've ever used fentanyl, but heroin was my addiction, and I've been in recovery for seven years. What would you say to someone who's just starting out in recovery? In recovery, I would tell them, don't give up before the miracle happens. The miracle. Yeah. The fire. The fire for recovery. I want to help others. I got clean in prison, but my last use was also in prison as well. When I got out, I went to a recovery house in Columbia and started to see that other people, just as bad as myself, they were killing it, and they were joyful, and they were helping others, and they had a fire about them. I wanted that. My first heroin use was about 16 years old in Cleveland, Ohio, where I'm from. We were doing oxy-cottons, and we didn't have any oxy-cottons, so we did some heroin. That's where my addiction just took off. So there's no going back? No, not after that. How long did that go on? Well, I'm 45, and I've been clean for seven years, so it went on for a couple of decades. In and out of prison, homeless, overdoses, funerals, mental wards, all of it. What helped? The best motivator for anybody to get clean and sober is pain, because you're not going to change if something's going good. You're not going to change if you don't have to. The best motivator for me was pain, shame, and guilt, sitting in a prison cell. My family was done with me, ashamed of me, and I had nobody and no word of turn. That was my motivator to change. When I came home from prison, my sister gave me a chance. Both my parents were passed away. All my grandparents were, but the most important people, my sister, my niece, they started to give me another chance. I started going to recovery meetings and building a family there. I started going to church and building a family there. Building relationships. When you think about addiction, when you think about recovery, I think about what the opposite of recovery is. I think that that is not being connected. I think that's the opposite of addiction. I got connected every way. Like I said, recovery meetings, church, community. I became a peer specialist working with people that are in active addiction or just got clean. I found my niche. What do you do now? You're paying it forward, it sounds like. Paying it forward. Sometimes it sounds really glorious and fun. I'm helping people get cleanest over. When you think of addicts and early recovery, it's not fun. Just because we pulled a needle out of our arm or stopped smoking a bubble or whatever your choice is, it doesn't mean that all your problems go away instantly. All that means is you're not getting high. The real challenge is now, now that you have to deal with yourself and all your trauma and yucky crap that you brought into recovery with you. Many early recovery people, their statistics are not great, but I get those twos and threes and four people that I sit back at the end of the day like, yep, this is why I do what I do. That's the cool part. Rehab, that's a really expensive way to get free information. That's not a popular opinion, but it's the truth. All those resources are out here in the community as well. I do believe that it serves a purpose, it helps them get to dope out of their system. The relapses, maybe it's me being cynical from doing this for a few years now. I expect people to relapse. It makes me extremely joyful when they don't. If I expect them to relapse, it doesn't take away from any effort I put into how I serve them or help them or anything like that, but it's okay. I get it. The most unfortunate thing these days is that when it comes to fentanyl, another recovery is not guaranteed. People are dying left and right, so relapse is not okay. I'll never sit here and be like, well, it's okay. I won't co-sign that. I won't. Relapse is not okay, but it's expected. The last thing that I always remind my guys is that these are not breaking bad characters in a surgical place making this stuff. These are sometimes foreign, sometimes whoever, but they're out here in these woods with stills and all this other stuff, and it's nasty, and there's no method to it. These are not scientists making these pills. Again, that's the scary part. A lot of times they're just junkies trying to get high too. Just because it says Adderall or Morphine or whatever on the pill, that doesn't mean nothing. That means that they bought that pill press off of eBay. What's the big things that people that are in recovery really need to know? What's the things that they don't know? Something I always tell people is get in the middle of the boat. If you're a fellowship person such as myself, you go to as many meetings as possible and you learn how to serve, and you build a support network. If you're not a fellowship person, you better find something to believe in. You better find something to fill that void because us as drug addicts and alcoholics, we live and breathe it. Our addiction is everything. My addiction was the most jealous thing ever. I wasn't allowed to have family, girlfriend, job, none of that. Just my addiction. When you take that addiction out of your life, it leaves a gaping wound, like a void. You need to fill it with something. God, recovery, something positive. Most of us, we're not just addicted to the dope. We're addicted to the life. Got to fill that void. I'm an NA person. I found my family there. I found people like me, knuckleheads, just like myself, that gave me something to do. They held me accountable. They didn't cosign my bullshit anymore. They wouldn't just accept any old answer. They made me really start taking a look at myself and holding me accountable, gave me stuff to do, gave me responsibilities, made me feel a part of their life. That's the biggest thing because we don't use drugs, fentanyl, whatever because we feel great about ourselves. You know what I'm saying? We use to hide this trauma and these feelings. When we start to experience a little recovery and people start accepting us, it means the world. It really does.
title: Mike's Story - The Fires of Recovery

transcript_whisper: It started with drinking first as a teenager. Yes, as a teenager it started with drinking and over the years it progressed and got worse. This is what I've been doing. So that was the moment where she suggested, Keonja, you need to go to Kentucky. You need to get in rehab. And it's also miles and miles away from Virginia. So the point of moving away from the area that you're used to and the people that you know was a part of the suggestion of going to Kentucky to kind of start over. And it actually was helpful, very helpful. It was hard to do in the beginning. And as I went through my process, but it was the best decision I ever made in my life. I believe it stuck because I had finally made up in my mind that that's not the life I want to live. I finally made up in my mind that I was tired. I was sick and tired of being sick and tired. I had finally made up in my mind that I want better for myself and my children. So even though I gained a lot of knowledge while being there, I also applied that knowledge. And that's what made it makes it powerful. I had to actually come to the point where, okay, I'm here in the rehab program miles and miles away from my kids and family. Clearly, I don't know a thing about life and how to live. So I had to humble myself. I had to listen to other people that had been there long before me and that were actually walking, walking it out. So I had to shut up, be quiet and take suggestions. I had to be open to that. I had to go into it in a mindset of knowing that, hey, I don't know everything because see, I always thought I knew everything. But I had to get real with me first. Keonjoo, you don't know all there is about how to live life and live it on life terms. So I had to listen. I'm still taking it one moment at a time. I'm taking it one step at a time. transcript_whisper: I Am an alcoholic and an addict I have been in recovery since February 24th of 2023 I Am hoping that just sharing my story will encourage others that recover is possible Yeah, on Saturday, it'll be 18 months And in that time I have been able to Get a lot back that I had previously lost I Have reestablished a connection with my younger sister and her family My mom and I are closer than ever But the catalyst to getting sober for me was unfortunately the death of my father He died on May 8th of 2022 and Before he passed away. I had decided that I wanted to Try to get sober I Signed up for outpatient services at a recovery center here in town and I did successfully complete that and I quit drinking alcohol I haven't had a drink since April 24th of 2022 But in my grief I discovered that I Was not just an alcoholic I would pretty much use anything that I could to Try to tamp down those feelings and grief is an incredibly uncomfortable feeling My dad and I had been very close he Was a pastor here in town he was always just the most honest and understanding man and So I was closer to him than I was to the other members of my family And losing him was really hard so You know because I knew he was sick was when I really started trying but Like I said grief can do some Really hard things to us I Had still been smoking marijuana a lot of people call it marijuana maintenance, you know for some people it is helpful, but for me it It just made things worse it made the anxiety worse it made the depression worse and I Didn't understand that at the time And eventually I started using other substances Because I just figured well, it's not drinking right? so The substance that I had the hardest time with is you know one of the dumbest that you could do I Started huffing air duster Because I knew that it Wasn't a lasting high and I thought well, you know, it's not an illicit substance but What it was doing to my body and my brain was Probably worse than the drinking I Ended up, you know really Doing a lot of damage to My body my brain and you know myself esteem I knew what I was doing was incredibly stupid But at the time it felt like the only way to escape the grief that I was feeling and It was easy to get I Ended up getting to a point with that where I was making myself sick. I was passing out it causes a lack of oxygen to the brain and There are chemicals in it that can potentially do you know damage your lungs among other things and I was To a point with it where my roommates at the time were afraid they were gonna find me dead so In order to You know Keep my job keep my living situation and keep my family I Signed myself up for outpatient services a second time It was actually the third overall but this was the time that I really took it seriously I went to a place here in town called mirror, Inc. They have them across Kansas, but the one here in Topeka was the one that Did the trick for me? I guess so to speak I Had an incredible counselor who tailored my recovery plan to my interests and What interested me was learning about why our Bodies and brains, you know want and crave these substances and what it does to us and I Think understanding and learning about those things really helped me So a lot of my homework was watching documentaries But I also just I Started taking notes I started really investing, you know more time in the hows the wise and the what's and Something clicked and stuck and Now that I do know Exactly what I was doing to myself looking back. It's scary But at the time that was all I knew I had been drinking and using different substances since I was about 13 years old It started when my family was living in Oklahoma City We moved back to Topeka. I was born here, but we moved back to Topeka around the time that I was 16 and For my generation drugs are everywhere They're easy to get it's scarier all the time I Have been drinking heavily essentially since I started drinking I Was somebody who drank to escape Or to fit in, you know, I always had to keep up with everybody and So that was a point of contention in my family and You know, my parents really tried they tried to understand they tried to get me help they You know, they knew that something was going on but Nobody is ready to see it until they're ready Nobody can get you sober except you The heavy drinking was I think the hardest because For a long time, you know, I knew that I was doing it as an escape, but I wasn't Looking at why I needed to escape And that's something that in my adult life I have focused more on Recovery for me does include a lot of therapy I I Didn't want to see it as a teenager though who wants to you know have a problem who wants to admit that they're different Whether it's substance use disorder a diagnosable mental health disorder, you know, nobody there's a stigma surrounding all of those things and And at the same time there's a bunch of people around you in school who are doing similar things Right as a kind of endorsement. Yeah of doing it and you know going from Everybody else doing it because it's cool to experiment in school. I went into the surface industry Where drinking and drug use are encouraged? It doesn't matter what kind of day you've had what kind of shift you've had you drink about it and There's also a lot of access to other substances In my 20s, especially it was drinking and cocaine I am very grateful that at the time Fentanyl wasn't as big a thing as it is now Because with the way that I was drinking and using I could have easily fallen victim to something like that It really started just as experimentation, you know in Middle school that was mostly just smoking pot in high school. It was drinking at parties And then it was harder drugs I Tried meth for the first time when I was 15 years old and It was because people had it I Trusted them. I wanted to try it So we're winding a little bit when I was 14. I was sexually assaulted and I think that The trauma from that really affected the Experimentation it went from I'll try it to Let's do it all the time because what could hurt me that didn't already hurt me and My parents knew that something was going on, but I didn't tell them for about a year that anything had happened and When they did find out It was after a particularly big explosion of emotion That was due to drinking And like I said my parents always tried you know, but The help that they wanted to get me I wasn't ready to take I was too angry at the world to do anything about it yet I'm still working on getting past that still angry at the world a little bit More so the trauma of that specific event. I'm less angry at the world and I am more angry at myself for Not Trying when help was offered. I Think a lot of addicts in recovery Have ourselves first on our resentment lists I Think it's a very personal thing if you prefer to refer to yourself as someone with substance use disorder That's all right. If you prefer to call yourself an addict. That's all right Recovery is personal and how we label ourselves as personal I Really appreciate people who have dedicated their lives to learning about addicts and substance use disorder and working with them, but Unless you have that lived experience It's not really up to you what we call ourselves Recovery is possible It's a lot of hard work There are days where You feel like why am I doing this? but It's really powerful to know that you can get through those days without using The life that I live now is The life that I've always wanted but I Was too afraid of feeling and doing the inner work for so long that It's a little postponed But just because it's postponed doesn't mean it's not beautiful Seeing The change in myself has been incredible when I started my recovery journey I started journaling and Looking back at the things that I used to write about and You know how that has evolved is Sort of like this tangible proof of life that I can hold in my hand and see You know just how far I have come in this process You

transcript_whisper: Way back in probably 2009, it started out with weed and alcohol. Back then it was in and out of jail and group homes because it was just trouble after trouble after trouble. We moved down to Texas in a small town called Eustace. That was at about 14. It was a small town of probably just a couple hundred people. I had my best friend down there and we smoked weed every day. All day that was our thing. One day we got a hold of some acid. We did the acid. We were told that if you smoke some meth with the acid that it gives you a better time. It gives you a better ride. We did it. At the time we thought it was great. It was fun. We got expelled and then went even further because now we don't have really any responsibility. At 16 you don't have school and what not it's what it is. We got pretty far off there. I didn't even go back to Texas. I was on probation in Texas, didn't go back. I ended up getting sent to KJCC here in Topeka and whenever that happened I got out right before my 18th birthday so Texas ended up dropping all their stuff because I already went to prison up here and stuff for it. The group home things kind of picked up a little bit. I was doing better. I had a job. I was working five days a week. I was there for like three months and I ended up getting into a fight and got kicked out of there. So then I went back to the Wyandotte County JDC and they sent me back to KJCC for three months. Three months at that time because I was still, actually I went to the county jail at that point. I was over 18. But I was still on juvenile stuff so they sent me back to KJCC. I got out after doing three months. This brings us up to the end of 2016, beginning of 2017. I went to live with my grandma and I did pretty well for a little while. It gave me something to kind of look forward to. I was part-time at Johnson County Community College for automotive tech. It seems like once the summer break hit, it just all hell broke loose again. It was very slow because I was trying to not lose everything. I thought that there was a way to do it and not get caught, not get in trouble. This brings us to mid-17. And finally, I lost my job. My juvenile probation violated, went to the county and the juvenile court gave me an unsuccessful discharge. I looked at that as a hell yeah at the time. I don't even got to sit in jail no more. I was done with all that. I thought it was free game. And that's where it really started at. That's where it went south very quick. transcript_whisper: For me working all 12 steps and sponsoring people today is really a whole lifestyle change. Being a service to others in any way I can and it's the career path I took now and it's been really rewarding. Just one of the main reasons that keep me sober today is being a service to others. So the things I get to do in my community now is I work with a non-profit agency and I do parent education and parent leadership. So being me in a person in recovery is I reach out to the people I can help the most who can relate to my stories and our parents, you know, the people that have kids involved and really get to reach out to them and make a difference in their lives. I had an opiate issue for almost 15 years when I first started doing it. I was about 14 and that's when it wasn't an issue but it gradually got worse and worse. One of the big things that got me sober was actually surviving an overdose on fentanyl. That's when I knew that things, I was Narcan by a friend who isn't here today now because of an overdose and I mean he saved my life that day and that's when I knew that I had to change it for my kids and myself because I wanted to be the father that they needed. And back then it seemed like, you know, just grabbing stuff out of your parents' cabinets or buying them at school and stuff like that but I was prescribed Adderall at a young age in a fetamines and it's something I realized I could trade for what I wanted because I found my love in opiates instead of, you know, that and it just kind of blend over to that line and it wasn't really an issue. High school was the weed, the drinking and the pills really, you know, and started, you know, dabbling in psychedelics and stuff like that but nothing seemed like an issue at the time, you know, and I got married at a young age right out of high school and that's when the whole journey with synthetic opioids at least really took off and I don't know whether, when the withdrawal started or when it really started going downhill is just, I can't place it but it turned into a problem, a huge problem in my life. It's somewhere in the line of when I started distributing, when I had them around me a lot more I'd say and that's when I had more access and it became more of a problem where I, you know, I didn't have to pay for them or have to go out and do things, you know, and it's just, it was a slope that went downhill pretty fast. I've always been a true alcoholic too and it's it runs in my family also with addiction and mental health and stuff so those were all huge things and of course getting in trouble with the law. I remember I failed probation just because of substance use. I remember going in there and I would admit to the opiate use because he knew that I was an opiate addict but that was just to keep him from finding, you know, the other three or four drugs I was on at the time also because a lot of it was couch surfing at the time and just following that road. It eventually led me to prison and being released from prison I maxed my time out and the year post release I'd say within two days of release, you know, I was sticking needles in my arm again and it was immediately downhill for a couple months and I broke down to my parole officer and I was like I need help. I can't stop and they were really good about it and put me in treatment here and you know that time I survived a good 18 months over. I am a huge advocate for Oxford houses too. I've been in Oxford houses probably five years and all. This time I stayed a good 16 months I believe that time and it eventually came down to wanting visits with my older daughter and she was born in that marriage and I got divorced from that marriage and I didn't have a safe place for her to be while I was working on my recovery so I ended up moving in with a friend and I told myself I was a normal drinker that I could have just one and be fine and all that and about three years later I crawled back and I was having alcohol related withdrawal seizures and every time I really wasn't dabbling into opiates but every time I tried to pick one up I would overdose and it happened twice before I really realized that this isn't the same anymore. It looked the same as it used to be but it just fell out immediately and stopped breathing and it's like that's not how it used to be and it's just not worth it no more. And unfortunately it was a friend that ended up passing from fentanyl overdose who saved me. He died about it's almost two years on those two close friends I lost. My best friend since I was five he died about 18 months ago from a fentanyl overdose and it's just really something that I tried to dive into harm reduction right then and get the word out because I was tired of losing people. I ended up putting him on my arm and says no story should end too soon. Purple ribbon and everything and I just wanted to take him on this journey with me too and I mean being around people that are losing kids to it and friends and family members it's just it's overwhelming sometimes. So the crazy thing is I got sober during COVID which was a really weird time and like the opposite of what everyone else is doing. But yeah almost dying was really that turning point I did it wasn't on probation or anything at the time. It had somebody telling me to do this. I was just scared for my life. I ended up checking in I had to do a medical detox because the way I was drinking. But with COVID they would set the bed date so far out. It'd be a month until you can get into a bed after the detox. The first time I went to detox it was you know I started drinking again because that bed date and I showed up at that bed date you know drunk and they didn't let me in. So I am so grateful for my parents today because after the second time I went to detox. I'll call it like a passive kidnapping. They took me into their house and you know took my keys to my car everything and would transport me to work just so I could stay good until that time. Until that new bed date and that might have changed everything for me. I did a 30 day program here in Topeka. Immediately went back to Oxford House. So I've been in recovery quite a few times at this point and the one thing I noticed that I didn't do was dive into the program of Alcoholics Anonymous and work these steps. So that's just something that I put in my head like hey I got a really good sponsor. I'm going to actually try to do it this time and he immediately put me into service work. So like I said last time I couldn't have any more safe to raise my kid while working in program recovery which led me into this opportunity of opening the first men in Children's Oxford House in Topeka. So this gave us a safe place to me and a couple dads to bring our kids over there, live in an Oxford House like other people do but also have our kids and it really set off this whole journey. I was there for over a year in which I opened up another one, the Buchanan House, the second men in Children's House in Topeka. So this whole time I took on my, she was probably two at the time, my little daughter Ava and I took her on full time while working in program and everything and working and doing the whole thing. It's just been such a blessing to watch these other dads thrive in these conditions. A lot of them want to be the parents they can be but they just don't know how to safely go about it in these homes or just a safe place to do that. It's been a recovery process plus you can have your kids around you. The other houses will allow that but we work with companies, not companies but organizations like KVC and state agencies to bring kids home from foster cares using these homes to reintegrate them and it's just been nonstop fulfilling this. I don't know how to describe it. It's really what led me into the career I have right now. I get to do parent education in my community and like I said it's a lot of the people I reach out to are the people that have been incarcerated or have mental health problems, have kids in state custody, dealing with substance abuse, just everything I can relate to. The courses I get around in the community now too because I learn off of fathers every day. I don't know at all. I don't think anybody's got parenting down. It's a new journey every day and it's being around especially the fatherhood stuff I do out here. It's being around other people that are going through it because a lot of it can be scary. Just having someone to talk to about it means the world to people. You don't have to be defined by your past. You can still make a difference out here. It took me, I had to work on myself for a long time to be able to figure out who I am and be able to move forward with my life and I do attribute that a lot to the 12 steps. Being able to sponsor people now, being a service to others, it's just a huge thing that opens doors and it's hard to describe it but there's just signs all around me that show me where I need to be and what I need to be doing. There's got to be this kind of, like in the course of your recovery journey, there's got to be these awesome little discoveries that happen fairly regularly where you see yourself, oh wow, that's better now. The promises of the program, it can be the smallest things at first like, hey I just got my driver's license back, all these, really learning how to adult again, you know, it's like I wasted so much time doing what I wanted instead of what was good for me and those small successes like that, like getting a visit with your kid after you haven't seen them in months, you know, or a driver's license, getting your social security car back, getting your first job while in recovery, it's just the promises of the program and they just keep building and building and repealing themselves.
title: Nathan's Story - In Service to Others

transcript_whisper: Why am I here? So I spent 36 years of my life in addiction, 33-time convicted felon, 28 and a half years of my life in prison. The first thing I would say is that I used to be part of the problem, the drug problem. In 2017 God revealed himself to me. I surrendered my life to Christ. I went back to prison for two years, two and a half years. I came home from prison January 20th or January 2020 and three months later they found my sister dead in a hotel. title: Addiction to Recovery - Paul's Mission

transcript_whisper: I have found freedom for the first time in my life after over 20 years of struggling in alcoholism and substance abuse, specifically meth addiction, and I am in recovery and I'm proudly in recovery. It's taken me a long time, a lifetime, actually a lifetime of relapse, incarceration, trying over and over and over again to find this freedom and I found it. I have found it. My childhood in upbringing was actually fairly normal. I grew up in a house, my parents were divorced, but that's super normal, right? Most parents are divorced these days and I didn't get heavily involved into alcohol until about my freshman year of high school and that was when I first discovered that alcohol made me feel powerful. It took away some of the pain of some of the struggles that I had been experiencing. One of the key moments in my life where things shifted for me, it seems like we all have those key moments in our lives where something happens in our teenage years and this is mine. My mom sent me to go live with my dad. I was 16 years old. I lived with him for about eight months and I was a little wild. I was a little wild and it was too much for my dad and my stepmom and they sent me back to live with my mom and the way that my 16-year-old brain interpreted that moment was that I wasn't good enough and that I didn't deserve a better life, that I...that's the best way to say it, that I just wasn't good enough. I dropped out of school when I got back to Texas after I had come back home to Texas and started drinking very heavily. I was hiding alcohol in my closet and it was a very short time before I was doing cocaine on a regular basis. I did manage to enroll into college throughout that time period but that didn't last because I was way too focused on having fun and drinking. And then there's a moment where it was no longer fun. And I think for people who don't have addiction issues, that's when they stop. And I didn't have an off button. I didn't know that I didn't have an off button but I didn't have an off button and I got involved with meth at around 21 years old and very shortly started shooting meth right after that time and committing crimes to support my habit and was just living that hard and rough lifestyle. It wasn't until I was 24 years old that things started to look up for me. I, through the midst of my addiction, got pregnant, which was an absolute saving grace for me. I had a little baby girl and was able to get clean and sober and I stayed that way. I stayed that way for four years. I married her dad. We lived a life and it was the very first time really since I was a child that I was able to experience something that was stable. I relapsed, which is such a huge part of my story. transcript_whisper: I'm here because I care very much about people that have went through the recovery process, people who have experienced loss due to substance use or abuse, and our future in regards to children that are coming up and being exposed to substances as part of growing up in a part of life. So I work at a prevention agency and being here not only supports the community and the message that is so important to the agency I work for and myself, but it speaks to how big of an issue this is and how many families are being impacted by fentanyl and overdose and substances in so many different ways. I think it's much bigger than we realize, but then I sometimes encounter people that have no idea. And then I am first a bit shocked and then a bit scared thinking how can we get this message out? How can we get more people to have an awareness and an understanding that this is a really very serious crisis and could be far more impactful than we've even seen so far. We lost over 106,000 people in 2023 across the United States. That is down a slight bit from 2022. I think a lot of those numbers are still a bit preliminary. It's hard to get final numbers with all of the work that goes into that. I think that we have areas in Kansas, particularly, that are more impacted. Our county, is Shawnee County, where the capital city is located. We're one of the top counties in Kansas that's impacted by overdoses. We have other counties that have big populations such as Sedgwick County with Wichita and Johnson County with Kansas City that are more significantly impacted than us. They're also larger, but it's alarming how predominant it is in Kansas. We have seen a decrease from 2022 to 2023 of about 4% in overdose fatalities, but we need those numbers to be significantly lower. Fewer families impacted. I think the cost of a human life is too much to measure. A lot of what we focus on in our organization is education of youth. We are in a lot of schools in our community thanks to funding from so many grants. We're able to go out and talk to kids about different substances and the impacts that they can have on their lives from their minds, their bodies, their ability to do athletics and the things that they love to do. We talk about the impacts on relationships and how substances can really impact people there. We also work on educating families and the community through different events where we go out and we talk about whether we have speakers come in or we go out and talk about the impacts of substances on people, whether it be fentanyl or stimulants. We talk about how to recognize signs of overdose, how to respond appropriately, how to administer naloxone. Really being a resource in our community in terms of helping people to understand what to do that this is not something that's isolated to certain families. It can impact anyone from a baby to a senior citizen. This doesn't choose. So education is the largest portion of what we do in our agency. We also do evaluations or assessments to really try to intervene early. A lot of those are with youth that are referred to us from schools that have been caught within a substance of some kind or under the influence of a substance of some kind. We are a stop that helps determine if they need more assistance, whether that be mental health support, whether that be support with substance use, really education for the family and the young person. That's a lot of what we do. I think people get wrong that they think that it could not happen in their family. That's not going to happen in our family. I think people think that individuals with a substance use disorder choose to have that life. They choose to use substances. They choose to live that way. What they really need to know is that we're dealing with individuals that are dealing with trauma, with crisis, with mental health disorders, with real human problems that all of us face. And maybe they don't have the skills at that moment or maybe they don't have the supports at that moment to be able to move forward. But substance use is something that can impact all of us. Overdose can impact all of us. And we just need to really have that awareness that none of us are immune to this occurring in our lives. We do not have enough resources. I really believe that we have got to have more resources. We need to have resources for people that are underinsured or not insured. We need to have access available when people are ready. Because I can't force someone to be ready. You can't force someone to be ready. They have to decide when they're ready. And when they're ready, we need to have a place available for them. And we need to be able to support them and walk with them and help them to get to the other side of this challenge that they're facing. And it may take multiple times, but they need the love and the support. Sometimes that's tough love to get through it, because it is something that you can recover from. Recovery is possible. I know people that have been in recovery for years. And I know people that are very new to recovery. And there's really nothing quite like carrying their stories and knowing the challenges that they've overcome and how their lives have changed so much. And the work that they're doing on the other side is so phenomenal. I'm so proud of my friends that are in recovery. I do see a lot of people that are have found great support in AA or NA. I also feel like there's people that have found their way through other programs, Smart Recovery. I think it impacts everybody different. Everybody needs to find the way that's going to be most successful for them. I feel like that network of support is pivotal. And AA does a great job of really wrapping themselves together as a community and supporting one another. And I think that is really pivotal for people that are in recovery is being able to relate to others that have had this similar experience, have walked through some of the same challenges, dealt with some of the same hurts. And knowing that you can call upon those people at any time has to be tremendous. So I think really whatever way people can find the greatest support forward is going to be huge. I think you reach out, you find a trusted person, you find whether that be someone in your family, whether that be a community resource, whether that be someone that's a trusted friend to walk with you, to help get you there, to drive you to the center, to be your cheerleader and support in the car, to hold your hand, to get you to whatever that place may be. And don't be afraid to reach out. I think that stigma keeps that from happening a lot of times. People are afraid, are nervous about how people might respond to reaching out to wanting to get help. And we've got to just really break that down and really work on supporting people, to getting to where they need to go, calling those numbers, getting in the car, going to the ER, going to the crisis center, going, you know, if there is a place, if you don't know where to go, just reach out to a friend, reach out to someone that can help get you there.
title: Finding the Path

Although I didn't know what he was doing at the time. And it's crazy because I was in like really bad neighborhoods, you know, neighborhoods that like I would kind of prefer not to even like drive down the road with my kid in the car. And that person is self-centered, difficult to deal with, all kinds of things that are involved in that character of that person. And when that same person is in recovery, they're generous. They think about other people. There's a whole different person that you're dealing with. It's part of the miracle of recovery and it's a wonderful gift to the world. Now somebody can say to me, okay, Bob DuPont, so you've had this lightning strike you and you've seen all this, but this is just something over the side. What's really going on to deal with this epidemic hasn't to do with those meetings. It has to do with this medicine or this vaccine or whatever it is that's going on, coming from science. I say, okay. But 30 years into the field, I asked myself, how good could outcomes be? Because the most striking thing about treatment of addiction is relapse. This is a disease. How could it possibly be? What would be the best it ever is? And I had the experience in my practice of having doctors as patients who were going to the state physician's health programs. Now a doctor in this country who has an alcohol or drug problem is going to go to the Board of Medicine where their license is. And they're going to get referred to the state physician's health program. Every state has got a physician's health program. And they're all different, but they're all the same also. And they'll do an evaluation of the doctor, the physician. Does he or she have a substance use disorder? If they do, then they're going to go to intensive treatment, typically a 30-day or 60-day or 90-day residential, but it could be outpatient. But anyway, they decided this is the best treatment for this person. And then for five years, five years, they're going to be subject to random testing so that every day for five years, they're subject to be testing and they're done on a random basis. And they get up in the morning and they see whether they have to have testing or not. This is every doctor in the country has this system. It's what they deal with. And then after five years, if they haven't used any drugs and had any problem there, and if they have a relapse, then they're going to go back to treatment again. Okay, how do they do with that? Now think about this. So first of all, I'll tell you that half of them roughly are alcohol of the doctors. A third are opiates and a sixth is everything else. So mostly it's opiates and alcohol that are being treated. And the treatment is the same for both. Same for both. Okay. 78% of those doctors never had a single missed or positive test in five years. Now think about that in relation to other patient populations. Come on. 78% random tested for five years and never had a missed or positive test. You don't have a real results like that. Nobody's got results like that. Well, why is this? Maybe because doctors are smarter. I don't know, not smarter. They have the same rates of addiction as anybody else does, actually. And it's because there's leverage there. The leverage is their practice, their livelihood. It's on the line. And by the way, it isn't just doctors. Commercial pilots have the same kind of approach too. And sometimes lawyers do, but not quite as much as the pilots and the doctors. And why is it pilots and doctors? Because of the concern for the public safety of the addicted person. That's why you get into this. But it's a very important thing. So somebody said to me, well, but that's why all this, what happens afterwards? What happens after they finish? And they do relapse from time to time, but very unusual. But what's most interesting is we asked them, what was the most important thing to you, this is five years after their last mandatory test, five years after the last mandatory test, we asked them, what was the most important thing to you in your getting recovering from this disease? And they had treatment, those treatment that they had at the beginning where they were in the residential treatment mostly, that was very important to them. Twice as high as that was going to AA and NA meetings. Now this is doctors. The doctors are going to the meetings. All of them were essentially are going to meetings. Not as a occasional person, but all of them were going to meetings. Why is that? Why did they ever get that program? How did that happen to be so different from what happens to everybody else? And the answer was that program was not started by experts like me. That program was started by doctors who were themselves in recovery. That's why it's so tough. It's not so tough to punish them. It's so tough because that's the disease we're trying dealing with. And that's what it takes to get people's attention and change their behavior. And I like to think that those doctors in their experience and God bless them are helping us understand the disease and what you do about it and what the recovery is like. And because these doctors are the ones that I've worked with quite exemplary, quite impressive. But anyhow, back to the basic message here. Cunning, baffling and powerful, lifelong and a matter of life and death.
title: ADDICTION: Cunning Baffling Powerful

transcript_whisper: I was abused as a child sexually and I really didn't know how to deal with it. I was in and out of the psych center and heavily medicated and some of my friends were like, hey, why don't you try this? And I did. How did that work out? It numb the pain and it was an escape for a long time. But it ended in me trying to take my own life. I knew I was addicted to things before I started using drugs because they started me on Ritalin when I was a kid, first grade. And I remember just the ups and the downs from that. I would get like a high and then when I would come off of it, it's like I needed more even as a kid, you know? I couldn't really function without it. Being a child and being prescribed to such a strong medication, I feel like it almost wires your brain to be an addict because it's speed. I mean, it helped me concentrate and it's calmed me down, but the real problem was still there. The real problem was I was abused. And so as you got older, you started getting into... Well, it started out weed and then pills. Of course, cocaine, you know, that was a drug of choice because I was on Ritalin my whole life. So I was looking for speed, you know? I was used to functioning at a much faster pace. So this normal life and no drugs, it felt weird. And then it went to alcohol, heroin, crack. Whatever I could get my hands on that would numb the pain, I was going to take it. And I didn't care what it cost me because I was living in turmoil my whole life. So I needed to get away. Did you have any resemblance of a normal life during this time or were you more... I don't even know what a normal life would look like. I've seen it on TV, what people look like normal. And I can't imagine what that's like. I have an idea of what it's like now at 46. I mean, I had dreams of things I desired to do, maybe. But each day I was just trying to get through the day and I want to kill myself. And I was in and out of the psych center my whole entire life. How did you wind up in there? Who would put you there? Would you put yourself there? No, my mother would. My mother and my stepfather and... until they couldn't and then... I would get arrested. I mean... Or I would do something that would put me in the psych center. I usually try to take my life. What helped? Well, I tried to take my life about eight years ago and I was on life support for four days. And when I came out of the medically induced coma that they had me in, I realized it didn't work. And God had me here for a reason. And no matter how many times I would try to take myself out, he wasn't ready for me to leave here. So I got locked in with a church. I got married. My husband's a big influence in my life for knowing Christ. And my church is a big influence in my life. Having a relationship with the Lord. Was that your first time involved in church? It was my first time with a relationship with Jesus Christ. I believed before, but I did not have a relationship. I still was medicated. I was still in therapy and prescribed medications. And I wasn't coming to it with a clear, clear thinking. It seems like you spent a lot of your developmental years in a kind of a fog. Yeah, you could say that. It almost doesn't even seem like it's my life. It seems like I was just there. It wasn't even my life. I was under the influence pretty much since first grade of medications, prescribed medications, or drugs. What are you thinking now? Just wow, how far God has brought me. I'm grateful. I'm grateful to still be alive. Because a lot of my friends aren't. They didn't find your path. They didn't. God chose me. And now I die to myself every day to live for Him. I was seeking God like I was seeking those drugs. So when you quit, was there a detox process that was difficult? Yeah, the detox wasn't as bad as some of the drugs I've come off of. I had dealt with a great deal of pain, so I was taking Suboxone and coming off of cocaine. So it wasn't as bad as it could have been. It was still hard. So where are you at now? A place I never thought I would be. I never knew how to get where I am. I just didn't know how to get to it. People told me, just trusting the Lord. And I did, but I just didn't. I couldn't get over the hump. I couldn't lay everything down. I still wanted to do it my way. But His too, and that didn't work. But you're in a good place now. I'm in a great place now. Great. What's so great about it? I feel free. I feel like all the chains that the enemy had on me are broken off. I feel like I can actually live. How's the living going? It's great. Recovery is hard. It's a hard process. But if you seek the Lord like you were seeking the drugs, it makes it a lot easier. It makes it easier. I mean, I'm just thankful for where I'm at. What is it that people who want to be in recovery but are not, what is it they need to know? That they can do it. It seems impossible. I know they're scared, but they can do it. Why can't they do it? Because if I can do it, I know anybody can do it. If you really want to get clean, you really want to start putting your family first and everyone that loves you, then you can do it. I'll tell you this, I could have done it without God. That's one thing I know. I've tried to do it myself every other way. But until I put Him first, and I mean before everything, I could not do it. That's what changed everything. Thank you. Thank you.
title: April's Story - Recovery and Faith

At that point, it was just like I didn't want to be there. I had no idea how to cope, how to be a person, how to allow somebody else to love me, how to love anybody else. You know, I lost my brother. I had gone to prison, I got out of prison and I was just, I wanted something different, you know, trying to stay high in order to escape everything. And you think you have this false sense of healing and you're just, you're reaching for healing and you're reaching for healing, but you're never able to grasp it because all you're doing is destroying yourself. I wanted that healing in my life. I wanted to overcome the traumas in my life that I had never given myself a chance to face. It wasn't until I decided to change and to do something different that I realized that's when the healing began. Like that's when I could actually overcome all the things that I had gone through. I made that decision, but I made that decision and I also had no support. Like I had nobody to back me up with those decisions that I was making, but I just, I seen something in myself that never gave up through everything that I faced, everything that I went through. I didn't give up on myself through all of that. I didn't love myself. I didn't have self-worth, but I noticed I didn't never give up and that was for a reason. So making those decisions, like I just decided whatever it was going to take, wherever it was going to lead me, even if it wasn't everything that I was wanting, I felt like I was worth at least giving myself a shot. So I got out and I had nowhere to go. I actually went right back into my addiction the first two weeks I was out of prison, but it was different this time. This time it didn't feel like an escape. It felt completely wrong. Like this is, I told myself when I was in prison, like we're going to get out and we're going to do it all different. And it felt different when I said it then. And when I got out and went right back to it, it felt different then as well. Like it wasn't for me anymore. And I struggled. I was bouncing. I was couch surfing, bouncing around from this person's house to that person's house. They were all using an active addiction. And I ended up at one of my friend's house who was doing a lot better in her life, you know, in her addiction recovery. And I told her everything that was going on. And I was like, you know, I messed up, but this doesn't feel like me anymore. And she herself was just like, you know what? I believe you and I want to see where you can go in your life. And her and her husband actually allowed me to stay with them for a month or two. And then I met a friend who traveled working in the pipe field and they had seen how well I was doing. And they were like, you know what? Come with me. I'll help you get a job. So I just leapt. I was like, this is it. This is the opportunity that I've been waiting for. I'm nervous. I don't know where this is going to lead, but I'm going to go for it. So I started traveling on the road. I was a pipe fitter helper and an expediter and that's all I needed. I just needed somebody to believe in me for the first time in my life. I needed opportunity and I needed to believe in myself and it made all the difference. How do you get to know? They are the most resilient people I have ever seen in my life. They were three and four at the time of this. Now they're 13, 14. And I have not seen them skip a beat. They are amazing. They're thriving. They're both so smart. They make straight A's sometimes in school. If not A's, A's and B's, they're excelling in their lives. And I admire them so much. They're beautiful. They're great. How do you get to know? Now, oh, you know, I never thought I'd see this side of life. I always thought, you know, getting sober and overcoming what I did, I thought my life would be okay. I thought it would be like mediocre, but God had other plans for me. I'm actually a board member and a case manager of an organization called Offensive, where I get to give back to people struggling like I once was. It's beautiful. I get to work closely with other organizations in my town. Jailers Boys, they're amazing. You know, if it weren't for them, you know, posting about this event right here, I wouldn't have even thought to come and tell my story. But I've got to see the amazing work that they do in the community. You know, I've been able to turn something so terrible in my life, all the family trauma, the dysfunction, the addiction. I've been able to turn it around to do good to help other people who are struggling and just be a beacon of hope. Offensive helps a lot of women. They help a lot of men as well. But I personally work alongside with the women. A lot of the women we work with, you know, have been in severe abusive relationships, family, you know, domestic, have been sexually trafficked, you know, lost in their own addictions and things like that. And so it's been a blessing for me myself to be able to give these women a little bit of hope in their lives and to see them overcome their barriers and achieve their goals. And it shows how resilient we can really be. I never thought I'd be on the other side of this. In my life, I was sure that I was going to die in addiction. I was sure that that's the only person that I could be. I never believed that I could be somebody giving back to somebody else. Like, you see these people with these badges and your addiction, and those are the people you're going to for help, and it's... You don't look at them and say, oh, well, I can do that. But now I am doing that. I am that person with the badge now. I am that person that can help somebody else. When first so long, that wasn't an option for me. I had fully convinced myself that. Because when you have the life experience, you're able to reach these people in a way, say somebody who just goes to school and they're learning from a book. You can learn about it all day long, but until you've lived it, you have no idea what that person is actually facing mentally and the challenges that they are facing in themselves and how can you combat the issue without fully understanding what it looks like to that person. So having the life experience, and I've had so many women tell me, we'll come to you and we'll talk to you because you know us. You've been us. You understand how I actually feel and what I'm actually going through. And with that, that's where lasting change happens. That's where real relation happens. That's when they actually have hope. Because you're not just a person with a book in front of them. You've been there, you've done that, and you've overcome it. So maybe they can too. Thank you. Thank you.
title: Addiction, Homicide, Trauma: I'm Still Standing - Gabrielle Francis' Story

transcript_whisper: The road began probably when I was 11 years old. Of course, started smoking pot. About 13 I ended up breaking my foot in half and got put on pain pills. Real high dose pain pills. And after that when the doctors tried to take me off of them, I just kept taking them and kept taking them. The only thing that kept me from getting messed up was to ride home. As soon as I got back to our neighborhood, I went right back to where I was hanging out. Family members, just stuff like that. It seemed like they were waiting there with open arms. It continued off and on, incarceration, rehabs, but every time I just didn't get it. November the 15th of 2021 was my first day completely sober and I've been sober ever since. I just decided that I wasn't going to get high no more and I kept my word. I've been sober for 26 months. I just celebrated the 15, 26 months. I can't guarantee nothing, but I know for today I'm not going to get high. I am in the recovery with a sober living community. I joined the Oxford House community 420 of 2022 and have lived in three houses, two of which I have went to restructure one because it was falling apart and it's successfully running right now. The second one, the third one, I had help open and it's been open since October and it's a prospering. Every person's got their own recovery program. Some people have to do the N.A. and the A.A. thing. Some people just, like I said, just don't want to do it no more. They just learned how to be adults again and you just got to strengthen your mind. Maybe it's for me, listening to other people's story that helped also that made me want to do better. Because I knew it could be done and maybe I heard somebody's story that I felt like that was me telling it up there. That's the only thing that seems to make sense to me whenever I think about it. And I must have heard somebody's story that I just felt like that was me. And what they did in the process of to get to where they are and I seem to be doing pretty good for myself right about there. It took me a couple of tries to figure it out, but I don't know. Like I said, this time it worked. That was the day after I got picked up. It was my first day sober because I did not get intoxicated or anything the whole time that I was incarcerated. And when I got out, I stayed sober. And I'm still sober to this day. I'm still accomplishing goals that I thought a couple of years ago before I got sober. I would never do. As in getting a job that pays 20 plus an hour. I got my daughter back in my life. Just driver's license, car, everything just falls in place when you're doing the right thing. You just got to keep going because it's not going to happen. You got to give up the instant gratification thing. Like when you were selling drugs or whatnot, that instant gratification is got to go out the window because anything that I have worked for has taken time. Subriety was right there at the beginning, but that's not all that it's about. You got to rebuild your life. Listen. Ask questions. There's so many things out there that can help you. And maybe like I said, it'll you'll just grasp onto something that just be your, your, you know, your cement. Stand on it and just keep building. You ain't going to build a house by imagining it. You're just going to build it by learning how to do it. That's just what works for me. And maybe it'll work for somebody else. That's the whole point of me telling it was going on. I've overdosed nine times. And by the grace of God, I'm still here. Fentanyl, heroin, opiates. I didn't met the amphetamines too, but my drug of choice was fentanyl, heroin, pills. The way I looked at it is fentanyl is cheaper than buying an oxycodone on the street. So if they press them into the pills and sucker somebody in the buying the pill, they're going to get more money out of it. They're mixing in with everything else. It doesn't even have to be pain pills, Xanax borers and all kinds of stuff. My life's back on track. I work. I'm able to pay my bills. It's just a different, I mean in the past I have been able to maintain, you know what I mean? But it was always a struggle. Now I don't have to struggle no more. I got my family back in my life to where like they trust me. To where they can call me and they know that if I say I'm going to do something, I'm there. I've got my daughter back in my life, which I was out of her life for multiple years in and out of incarceration, you know, in and out of drug use, stuff like that. And I was mad at the time that they kept her away from me because I still wanted to be in her life, but I understand why they did not. I've come to an understanding with my life that all the things they did weren't out of hate. It was out of love to make sure for her and for myself because I don't want to be in and out. But now I don't have to. I've come to learn that I'm completely at ease to know exactly why everything was done and to be able to face it, head on and hear why they didn't. And actually be able to understand. They tried to explain it before, but I wasn't trying to hear it. If you want it bad enough, you will go and get the help. That's when you're ready, you're ready. You'll know when you hear rock bottom, you know when it enough to move. And you'll take that step. You'll reach out, whether it's to somebody like myself that just has been through it and I can help you. Or you can figure it out on your own. I can steer you in the right direction, but I'm not going to do it for you. Because if I do it for you, that's just me enabling you to do whatever you want to do. It makes me look at things like to want to keep doing what I'm doing because it's... I know that I planted that seed. It might not grow right now, but it could grow in the future. And to know that it's there that when he's ready, he can do whatever he needs to do to get it done. Or she. I just hope that everybody takes some advice and if you're still out there doing what you're doing, it ain't worth it. There's avenues for every direction you want to go and I hope you guys take the right one. Thank you.
title: Recovery: Zach's Road

transcript_whisper: My name is Dene Jones. I'm here to tell my story of recovery. It is long and eventful and heartbreaking and exhilarating and I'm ready to tell it. So that's why I'm here.
