When I did get a chance to get out and hang out with friends, I just wanted to take advantage of it as much as possible. I wanted to have as much fun as possible. To me, getting obliterated, that was definitely it. By the time I was like 18, graduated high school, that's what I was known for. Go to Denise's house. She's going to have a party. There's going to be all kind of alcohol. I was always super inventive with the stuff I made. I would make all these drinks. It wasn't just a keg. It was like a keg floating. It was just the most. But I took pride in it. People would wake up with people passed out in my apartment. I was so proud of that. I was like, oh man, I did great last night. Victory. Victory. Everybody is obliterated. I carried that like a badge of honor. If you want to have a good time, let me know. I got you. I was so proud to be able to say I can drink any man underneath the table. Try me, please. But at the end of the night, I was just nothing. I was absolutely nothing. I gave so much power away to people to tell me my worth. If I wasn't the most popular person in the room or the one everyone was looking for, I felt like I was doing something wrong because my worth was so tied up in how much people loved me and how much I loved myself. But I didn't realize that for many years. Lived in Alabama for a while, and then we moved to Texas. So I moved to Texas when I was 21, well I was 20. And coming from a very small town in Alabama to Houston, Texas was a game changer in all of the wrong ways. I was even scared to drive on the freeways for the first six months. I had never experienced anything this big. There was like five lanes. That was nuts to me. But once I started getting my bearings, I started getting to know people and making a group of friends that I really felt were good for me at that time. But again, like I said, I was 21. So my friends at the time were all younger than me. I was the one who was legal to buy alcohol, so that was my job. I bought all the alcohol. I went all to liquor stores. And I kept the party going as much as possible. But after a while, you know, the party caused a lot of problems. There was a day when I was, you know, Sunday brunch. You go out. It was a football season, so we were going to go watch the game. We went to brunch first. I always loved wine. I could finish a bottle of wine in one sitting. Seven days in Harris County. And that was the scariest thing that ever happened to me. I slept on the floor. There were no beds. They didn't have any more cots. They didn't care. They didn't care. I'd never experienced anything like that. My bond was so high, we didn't have that type of money. And I just remember my lawyer reading to me the police report while I was like behind that glass. And I was so ashamed. I couldn't believe it. I just couldn't believe it. I didn't remember it, but I also couldn't believe it. And I had to call my mom. And there was so much disappointment in her voice. And she answered the phone. It broke me. And my attorney told her, you have to sell everything. That's just replaceable. We got to get her out. I was suicidal. I remember I had a dress on that day and I had like a tie. And they asked me, are you okay with this tie? Are you going to hurt yourself? And I said, yeah. If you leave me alone long enough, I will. So then I was put on a suicide watch. That was terrible. And I remember when I got out, they let you out of just like this back street. I think everybody, if you've ever been to jail, you know where that is in Harris County. It's just this little building. And my mom was parked outside. And I felt like a zombie. Like walking to her car. I mean, I was so detached from reality. And I remember her telling me that she didn't even know who I was. Never seen me look like that. And she took me home. And as soon as I got home, I got in my car and I drove to the liquor store. And I bought two bottles of wine. And I came right back home. And I remember when I sat right in the middle of my living room, popped them open and just drank them and then passed out. Because I knew what I had done had forever changed my life. And it was no one's fault but mine. And then now I was going to be on probation. I was going to be drug test. Everything about my life was going to be monitored and watched. And so instead of thinking, okay, well, this is the time to probably get my shit together. Like this is real. You have a felony. What are you doing? I didn't do that. Instead I thought, okay, how can I get around this? And the best thing that came out of that was I was court ordered to go to therapy. And I met my first therapist. His name was Lucky. And he saved my life for sure. I'd never had somebody be so patient and kind with me. Because I had completely now given up on myself. I had no value. I was a felon. I was a drunk. I wasn't working. I had no money. And any money I did have went to the state. No one would hire me. I, I, I, there was, there was nothing inside of me anymore. I just was existing. And for at least three months, I would go to therapy and not say one word. I would just sit there and look at him. And he just looked at me and he would say, we're just going to keep doing this until you're ready. And finally one day I was ready. And that's when I learned about therapy and how powerful and helpful it is. What it means to have support, to have someone that says, it's okay, it's all right. It's totally fine. We're going to figure it out together, me and you. We're going to figure it out. And he did that for me. He was patient and he was kind. He fed me when I didn't have money. He took the time to really see who I was. And when I would talk down to myself, he would tell me that that's not who I was. And that was the first real step of change I believe that happened in my life. But I just couldn't fight the addiction. I couldn't stop. And then I lost a job. It was a really good job. I've always worked in mental health. I've always worked in psychiatry. I love helping people. I love learning about the mind. I decided to go back to school when I got out. I wanted to be a counselor. And while I was in school, it was like my rehab, right? I was just learning so much about the brain and why we do the things we do in addiction. And I was going to a psychiatrist trying to get my mental health together. And the psychiatrist told me I was bipolar. And I don't know why that hit me so hard. It was kind of like, this is, I work in this field for a living and I can't even recognize bipolar symptoms in myself. I do assessments. What, what's going on? And I felt like I didn't know myself. I was like, I don't know anything about me because I was just listening to what everyone's telling me about me. And if I didn't know me, why am I here? So I tried to drown myself in the pool in my apartment complex. I just walked right in there and just sat there at the bottom. But I called my mom before I did it, which is, you know, we know it was a sign that we didn't really want it to happen. And I think that I did because she came immediately and she dragged me out. And I just remember screaming at her, I need help. I need help. And that was the first time that I was put into like a mental health facility. And I'll never forget when I went to the hospital after trying to commit suicide, I was telling the nurse, I need to go like into recovery. I need, I need treatment. I need something. And she said, well, your insurance isn't that good. You know, there's not going to be many places that are going to be able to have you. And I was like, I don't fucking care. Someone has to help me. Someone has to help me. I'm not leaving. And I spent two weeks and it was the best thing that ever happened to me. I was around other people that went through what I went through, other women. And that was a feeling I never had. I never was around other supportive people who felt what I felt or who knew what I was going through. And they were right in front of me and they were patting me on the back and telling me that I could do it. And I felt like a million bucks. I was like, oh, I've got this now. I'm good. I was sober for maybe like six months after that. I was healthy. I was working out. I was exercising. I was getting all my classes. There was like this joy that came back to my life. I was just so happy to still be here. I was so blessed to still be alive. I was so happy. And then it's like depression, you know, it comes in waves, you know, some minutes you're way up and then you'll be back down. And I don't know if it was just life in general, you know, because with abuse, I mean substance abuse every day is not guaranteed, right? We're just trying to make it the next 24. And something, just a mix of life and jobs. I just said, fuck it. I need a drink. What's the worst? I don't have to tell anybody. This is when I got through like the, I'll keep it a secret, you know, no one has to know this is just me and my addiction. I can die or do it however I want to do it. It's mine. It's my life. I can't fucking fuck what they think. And I'm not going to tell them either. And so that's when I started hiding alcohol and thinking that no one knew, which I knew I was showing up smelling horrible, glazed eyes glazed over, just denying it, embarrassing myself. I mean I was at a, I was pretty low at that point because I had experienced sobriety. I knew how great it was, but I realized I couldn't get to it. Not on my own. I would have to sit on my hands. I would try to not leave and go drink. I didn't have a car at this time. So I would just walk. I would just get up and walk straight to the liquor store, work to the gas station anywhere I could. And so I remember having to like literally sit on my hands and just say, God, please, please, please, please, please. It just, it felt like this overwhelming like force calling and like pulling at me, like just pulling at me, like grabbing me and just slowly pulling me closer. And it was unbearable. It was so unbearable. And I didn't have the words to explain it to anyone. And when I would try to ask for help, it felt like somebody had their hand over my mouth and was like covering it. And I was trying to scream through and say, please, but I couldn't, I just couldn't, I couldn't get the words out. I just couldn't. And these were really dark, dark times. So I isolated myself. I didn't talk to anyone for like a year. I just would go to work and come home and drink. That's all I did. That's it. That's where everything went. Something about addiction that makes us think that every worst thing about us is true. And no one can tell you differently. I don't know how else to explain that, but to say it just like that. No one can tell me that I'm better than what I am because this is all I have. I've never known anything more. And I was sitting there like, what are you doing? Are you in jail again? Is this where you want to be? Is this what you want? Is this all you think that you can do? Are you even going to try? You haven't fought for yourself yet. You fought for what people believe you are. You fought for what people say you are. You let society tell you that just because you went to jail, just because you have an addiction that you mean nothing. I have value. And I realized that. And I fought for myself this time. And I really made a conscious effort to pay attention to my health, do things that made me feel better, work out, go to therapy, do some support groups, whatever I needed to do, and then COVID hit. That was two years ago in some change. And it was just like this immediate click of, are you going to continue to hurt everyone that loves you? Are you going to continue to put the people that stand up for you through pain? Why are you doing this to them? Why are you doing it to yourself? I mean, it was literally that quick, that easy. It was done. It was dead. Dead. And it was the easiest this time. And I don't know if it's because I've been to school now, so I understand the behaviors, the attachment. I understand it all, all the science behind it. But it was more of the spiritual aspect that came in this time. I realized that I was worthy of love. I'm worthy of great things. The things that I can do when I'm sober blow my fucking mind. I mean, when I really just focus on myself and growth and whatever I want to do, that was the best part of sobriety. I can do anything. I can try playing the guitar. I can go out and learn salsa dancing. I can go to the park and lay out and read a book. I can go bike riding. I can do any of this shit because I was stuck to a bottle all day. I never even, I wanted to do it, but I never even thought it was possible because I'm too drunk to do it. Or my brain wouldn't even let me formulate that as an option. And once I realized that I could get sober on my own terms, I didn't have to do it the way AA taught me. I didn't have to do it the way my sponsor taught me. I could do it whatever way works best for me. And that's what I did. I made my own routines. I created my own support group, Sober Girls Houston, because I realized support is what you need to survive. We're humans. If we don't have other humans around telling us good things and helping us grow, lifting us as we climb, we're just here just bumping around into each other, serving no real purpose. And I had to find that group. I had to find that support. And that was the most important thing to me in my sobriety, in making a safe space for other women because there aren't many. You're so raw when you're in recovery. I mean, you're just, you're just raw with feelings and emotions that you've never had before because you've numb them for so long. So the most important thing is to feel somewhere where you feel loved and safe. And I was, you know, my best friend got sober at the same time. So I really, I call her my sober anchor because when things get hard or I need someone to talk to, I have her. She doesn't live here, which was a big thing because I realized, oh, I need someone like actually here in the state with me. I need people. I need people. And I had to cut out all the people that didn't have my best intentions. I still like to go out. I still want to have a good time, but I had to teach myself that you don't have to be inebriated to do that. You can just go out, have a good time and remember it tomorrow. That's cool too. When you're in addiction, you're so, we're so smart, right? We're always plotting and planning and scheming, getting this money together to get this next bottle or getting this money together to buy these pills. We're always making a plan. Like, you know, as soon as you wake up in the morning, your day is already focused around getting your, you know, your bottle or getting your pills, whatever it is, you've got it all planned out. And so when you get sober, you can use that same creative energy into something that's actually beneficial for your life, right? So now when you get up, you're like, okay, I got to get this done. I got to get that done. And it just works in a different way. And so I think that was a big thing for me was realizing like, holy shit, I'm pretty smart. Like, if I need to get something done, I can get it done, you know? And I really felt stupid for so long, you know, I just kind of was like, uh, this is the best I can do when really I wasn't trying at all. You know, so being able to have that clarity to really put your goals in order and attack them one by one is something that sobriety gives you that's extremely powerful, that can help you set your life up in a way that you never even imagined, never even dreamed of how it could be. It's so good over here, I promise. I promise.
title: THE JOURNEY From Addiction to Recovery - Danay's Story

transcript_whisper: I lost my leg because of fent law and I know how deep in the trenches it can take us so now I've dedicated my life to going around telling my story in hopes of using my pain for the purpose of lifting others out of the darkness before it's too late for them. That's what I dedicated to full-time. We'll get into my van out there in the parking lot. This is the first journey for my van we call the Hillmobile. It's built out as a full RV. That's my house on wheels. We named it the Hillmobile. The group that I started about 13 months ago, we call the Hill family. Hill was an acronym for help, empathize, accept, and love. And like I said, fent law took me into dark places. I never even fathomed were possible. I went from being a soldier in the army to a homeless IV addict. I mean, it's just before you even realize that there is a problem, it has became so much of an overwhelmed strength in your life that it's beyond what you can fathom just by normalcy. There's nothing normal about it. For instance, me, I was a senior in high school in 9-11, happened. So I joined the army. I go in and since there was such a large influx of individuals pouring into the military all at one time, there were some safety precautions that were being overlooked. A harness failed and I fell from about 15 foot and landed standing upright and snapped both my legs. So at 19 years old, I was medically discharged from the army. I'm a service connected veteran because of this, but I was given the parting gift of an opiate addiction. For seven years, I went to the doctor and got my prescriptions, thinking that when the doctor said, you need this, that I needed it. Not realizing that the reason why it made me feel good was because I was getting intoxicated and it's going on and on and it's building up and up. And you don't even realize how big it's gotten until all of a sudden the government says, oh, we're giving out too many opiates. I get cut way back. I learned what withdrawals were. I mean, I didn't even realize that I had a problem until the problem was life controlling. And then somebody said, hey, I got a buddy that sells those on the street. That become too expensive very fast. Hey, you know heroin will do the same thing. Before I realized the snowball that was going on, I was a homeless IV addict. I was living in abandoned houses. I was at the bottom of it, man. And it had total control of my life until December 20 of 2022. When I got so intoxicated on illicit fentanyl, I laid there unconscious while kerosene heater fell on my leg, burned it so bad that they ended up having to amputate it. I was in Burn Unit ICU in Chapel Hill, North Carolina from December 20 of 2022 to February 8, 2023. And during that whole time in the hospital, you know how many friends from the street came and seen me? Not a one. But within 24 hours of me getting released from the hospital, the dealer that sold me the stuff called me. I said, I heard you was out of the hospital. I got that fire if you need any. So I got enough fire from you last time. It got laid on my heart that true love, because what the streets show you is not true love. True love is what matters. And that's where the Heel family was born. I started watching, I was wheelchair bound for about seven months. And I started watching recovery content on Facebook and TikTok and all them. And I happened across Benjamin Lerner, the man that introduced me, we was talking about at the Lost Voices Offent All Rally. This is how I met him. I started watching his content. Then a man named Josh Catlett, I contacted both of them, told them a little bit about my story, and they both invited me to come on with them and tell my story. So August 27, 2023, I went on Josh Catlett's YouTube and told my story on there. Three days later, I went on Benjamin Lerner's radio show. He hosted a radio show in Vermont called Clean Jams. I went on it three days later. And within a week, I had received over 5,000 messages of people reaching out telling me that they had been inspired through this. They were having problems with that. And it clicked to me, this is what I'm supposed to be doing. So I started a community we call the Heel Family. I started sharing my story. We started going out and doing communal events. March the 2nd, 2024, we hosted our first community event. We did a overdose awareness skydiving event at Skydive Rally in Raleigh, North Carolina. I had members of the community submit pictures of lost loved ones, and we wore collage shirts and took them on a jump with us. Then I went back to the town that I was burned in, the town I lost my leg in, Danville, Virginia. Went back there with a group, my whole family, a group and a few of my followers. We wouldn't pass out over 2,000 doses of Narcan, some canned food and different things of that nature. And it felt really good to go back to the town that I feel like I took from for so long. Living there as a homeless IV addict, all you do is take. When you're in that world of addiction, all you do is take. And so the entire concept of what Heel is about is about helping others. It's about lifting up others. Last year, exactly a year ago, I put a post on Facebook saying, theoretically, if I bought a van and I build it out as an RV, to travel the country as a volunteer motivational speaker, how many of y'all would ride along with me? And I got a positive response. In May, I bought the van. It's a 1993 Ford E-150, big high-top conversion van. And for the last seven months I've took and I stripped it down to bare metal and built, it's my home on wheels. It's the complete RV. And yesterday was the start of the first trip yet for the Heelmobile. It's finally on the road. Anybody wants to hop in that passenger seat with me? Let's take his trip because it promises to be a fun one. What I tell everybody is, if it's a town hall meeting, if it's a recovery center, if it's a book club, if it's something positive to send me a message, and I want to travel the country as a volunteer motivational speaker, just going all over, just trying to tell the story of how dark it can get to hopefully show them the beautiful light that could be at the end of the tunnel.
title: Recovery - David Riggins' Story

transcript_whisper: I am the worst type of addict, and I say that not like degrading myself, but any mind-altering substance. I truly love not feeling myself. I always had to be numb of some way, shape, or form. Any chemical that I can get my hands on that would change how I felt was definitely what I would do. I'd go for it. So I've had tremendous problems and horrific addictions to the majority of the downers, the opiates, and the stimulants. Those were my drugs of choice for a long, long time, 21 years. I took my first hit of crack cocaine at 12 years old from my stepmother. I was in a crack accident with my dad in Colorado, and he was drinking and driving. He rolled the car, and we rolled eight times. He got ejected on the second roll and was deceased. He died there. Then the next day, I saw my stepmom and my older brother in the bathroom smoking something, and 12-year-old curiosity. I went in there, and I'd seen what they were doing. Of course, I wanted to try it because they were doing it, so I wanted to do it. I took my first hit at that 12-year-old right after losing my father, and I fell in love. Most people say it would have been so hard on you, but I grew up in an extremely chaotic, alcoholic, drug addict family. The fighting, the violence, the hatred was out of control. There was no real love there except for my mom, but it kind of dwindled away as her alcoholism progressed to a point, well, until she drank herself to death. Yeah. People, my life, I've been told by numerous people when I tell my story of different rehabs or facilities or detoxes. When I go in, they say I should contact Lifetime or Hallmark, because my whole life story would be a perfect movie of the real growing up in an addicted family. Growing up, I think there was short periods of time where it was normal. Our normal was my dad drinking or getting drunk and only hitting my mom a couple of times a night. That was my normal. I think I compared my life a lot to my friend's life. I would see my friends from school or where I lived. David had such normal lives, and that was taboo to me. I'm like, why is it like that? They're so loving and caring. I'm like, it's weird. But eventually, I'd be jealous. I'm like, I really want that. I want a loving family. So I didn't get it until I actually met my partner. That's when I actually felt that love from another person that I should have had my whole life as a kid or growing up. I'm grateful to be alive. I've OD'd three times in my life. The last time, it was probably the worst. It was six Narcans, and I was dead for 21 seconds. I don't know why I'm still here, but it was enough to shake me to my core. I never want to go back to that again. I think it scared me enough. At that point, when I OD'd, it was, I was already at a point in my addiction where I just wanted to die. I had no hope of living. I tried to get sober numerous times. It had never worked. I just couldn't, I could not put it down on my own. But ever since that OD, I have never felt such desperation to stay sober in my life. It's like an overwhelming feeling of, no matter what, I'm staying sober. And I wake up with it every day. I remember exactly, I wake up, I remember exactly what I went through, and it just helped drive me to stay sober and help other people. That's where I'm at right now in my recovery. I really help a lot of people in my network of sobriety people. I remember waking up to a light almost similar to this. It was in a hospital, and I had probably had six doctors around me. And they were just, if I could just print the image from my brain on paper of their faces and jaws and just their mouths were wide open, or like, we don't know how you're alive. We don't. And I remember once, a lot of them cleared out, one doctor, he said, kid, you're going to die next time if you do this. I guarantee it. And that kind of gave me enough to, like, I realized he was serious. And I realized that was my third overdose. And I'm too scared to test it. You know, I'm not a cat. I don't got extra lives. But I do know that I was at a point where I just wanted to be done. And I just couldn't, I didn't know how to be done. And I think that overdose just, it shook me up to do whatever. And it gave me the ability to actually listen to other people. Like people who were actually trying to help me, good, positive people, recommending rehabs and okay, I'll go, I'll do it. You know, instead of, oh, I got this, I'll do it on my own. Because I, 21 years of addiction, I've never once had it on my own. I can never have done it on my own. So it gave me that ability to actually listen to the advice and what other people are trying to help me with. It was scary at first. You know, this, I've been to a few rehabs in my life. And this one, it was scary because I didn't, I didn't know if I was going to have any permanent damage from that overdose. As the doctor stressed it was, you may have, you know, permanent damage. It just, we don't know until, you know, as you get yourself back to normal. But the rehab, when I got into detox, I was excited at first. And then, you know, of course, with the withdrawals, they started, they started coming on and I was, you know, blessed to be in a detox where they were able to medicate me to where I didn't have to feel such severe. And that's, so it made it a little bit easier. But after the detox phase, I was, I was excited. I was just, I was happy to be sober and happy to get sober. I have been in and out of sobriety 21 years, my addiction, 21 years I've been dealing with this. And it took, for me to stay sober, it takes the gift of desperation for me. I can't vouch for everyone, but for me it takes the desperation that I feel and I pray for it every morning because it's, I don't want to lose it. I feel that if I lose that gift of desperation that I may start going back to old ways, going back out. And that's, in that part scares me. So I wake up, I pray for that. I joined, so after rehab I joined a Alcoholics Anonymous. And I say, I use Alcoholics Anonymous because the Alcoholics Anonymous program is the founder of 12 Steps, which the recovery program of all recovery programs, that is the founder of it, like the grandfather of it. And I found that the type of addict that I am, even if I take a drink of wine or alcohol, my brain, something happens in my brain where I go off to, I straight to fentanyl or straight to the other stuff. So I do Alcoholics Anonymous as my sobriety, my program. And I joined the clubhouse here in San Antonio and I just dove in. You know, I didn't let my scared, being scared get ahead of me. I just, I raised my hand, I found a sponsor. And the people that I let in my circles, so my circle is fairly small. I got five people, but it's five people that I love unconditionally. They're there for me 24 seven. I mean, there's times where I'll wake up from a dream, a using dream, and I'll call them, like two in the morning, and they'll answer. I don't have to worry about them never answering. But I do the steps. I fellowship. That was a huge one for me because in recovery, a lot of young people, especially like me, we get bored really quick. We a lot of us can't sit still. We just get sick of doing the same thing, which is, you know, work, meeting, steps, home. You know, like a routine almost. And for me, I had to change that. I had to shake it up. I had to get involved with the clubhouse, which they have events. They have, I mean, every month we have something going on, whether it's fundraisers or awareness. You name it, it's what keeps, and that's what keeps me sober. Especially at the end of the day, I'm so exhausted from just doing everyday stuff with the clubhouse alone, never alone my personal life. It's what keeps me sober. I haven't had the thought to use since. You know, and it's, I've been tested in sobriety. Big triggers for me. The loss of the loved one, like of my dog, I had to put my dog down. And my dog was my best friend for 13 years of my using. She went to rehab with me. And I did that, and I got to stay sober through it. And the only way I was able to do that is with the help of my friends, my fellowship, my clubhouse, and my sponsor, of course. So that is like, I can't stress it enough when I talk to other people in programs, like staying sober is the struggle. Anybody can get sober, anybody can get sober for 24 hours. It's staying sober for that stretch, the long time, and that's the tricky part. And I think everyone's different. Everyone has their own way of doing it. For me, it was, I had to throw myself in there and be involved and continue to be involved. I'm doing other stuff with other areas of recovery, like sharing my story. That is, it's the highlight of my month. I'm doing it three times a month now. Different parts of this, you know, San Antonio, the rehabs, detoxes, or psychiatric hospitals, or even jails. I don't know, I haven't gotten there yet, but I am signed up. It's, you get this overwhelming feeling of like, I know my story can reach someone and help them. So it's just, it's exciting. Never lose hope. I think that was, there was parts of my life where I was so down in the dumps and, and I thought, I always told myself, this is it. This is what my life is going to be, you know, homeless, destroyed my life, killed relationships, and I couldn't keep a needle out of my arm. I accepted that. And there was times where I had lost hope. But there was always somebody else in recovery. You know, I know that people that, people that watch this, I, I just hope that if they're struggling with addiction, or if they have no someone that's struggling with addiction, there's no, they don't have to plan some big intervention or, you know, wait for them to destroy their life. It's what we call in AA is planting the seed, the seed of sobriety. And it was planted in me very early on. So, you know, taking someone to an AA meeting or just getting them a book, an A book or AA book or whatever sobriety book. And just getting that, just getting that seed planted. I think that that made the biggest difference. So every time I knew, I felt like I was done using, say I was on a bender for a month or six months. And I knew I was sick of it. I wanted to go back to sobriety. I knew exactly where to go. And that was, you know, to an AA meeting or to an AA meeting or heroin and on this meeting. And the second you walk into one of those meetings, someone will greet you. It's, it's, I've never had someone not greet me, except in a Spanish meeting. I didn't, I didn't know Spanish. I didn't know I was walking into one of those. They are like looking at me like I was an alien or something and I'm like, oh, wrong meeting. But, um, it's somebody will always reach their hand out. And that's, you know, that is, that is such a comforting feeling if you're just in a hopeless state of mind and you just want sobriety. Even if it doesn't stick, you just, just to go and feel that compassion that someone's still there, people are still there to help you. That is the biggest thing I can, I can recommend to anyone.
